Trump is giving Iran an ultimatum: cut a deal now, or he will provide Israel with bunker buster bombs.

This story has deflated the betting that the US will enter the War.

The "truth" below shot up expectations that the US would enter this war, as indicated by this chart.

Right now, the reason is unclear.
FOX: TRUMP REQUESTS NSC BE PREPARED IN SITUATION ROOM

*TRUMP TO RETURN TO WASHINGTON TONIGHT, WHITE HOUSE SAYS

(He is in Banff, Canada, for the G7 meeting now. So, whatever it is must be big to get him to immediately leave.)

S&P futures are trading now and have given back half of today's gains.

Trump's "truth" is being looked at as a warning that "something big" is about to happen.

Trump stated on Truth Social that Iran should‚Äôve signed the deal he offered to them, calling it a ‚Äúshame‚Äù and ‚Äúwaste of human life‚Äù that they didn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúEveryone should immediately evacuate Tehran!‚Äù

Second ...

Friday, June 13, was the holiday of Shavuot, and the Israeli market was closed..

Today, the Tel Aviv 35 stock index (35 largest Israeli stocks) rose 1.82% to a new all-time high.

Israeli stock investors NEVER lost money over this attack.

1/2

Market signals about the progress of the Iran-Israel war...

The Israeli Shekel strengthened against the dollar by the most in 28 years (bottom panel).

It is also STRONGER now than it was on June 12.

As this thread detailed, the market was NOT viewing Israel/Iran as the start of WW III.

It was correct to do so.

Earnings and Economic events this week

üßµ Why has The Free Markets ETF (Ticker: $FMKT) invested in Uranium Energy Corp Ticker: $UEC? Let‚Äôs analyze this strategic move in the context of deregulation, energy policy, and AI-driven investment selection. A deep dive into how regulatory shifts create opportunities. 1/10

Learn more about $FMKT at freemarketsetf.com.

Lead-Lag Publishing, LLC is not an affiliate of Tidal/Toroso, Tactical Rotation Management, LLC, SYKON Capital, Point Bridge Capital, LLC or ACA/Foreside.

The bottom line: $FMKT ‚Äôs investment in $UEC represents a textbook example of their deregulation thesis. As the uranium market faces a bullish outlook with widening supply deficits and strong policy tailwinds, UEC stands positioned as a key beneficiary. 10/10

$FMKT targets industries primed for deregulation, with energy specifically highlighted. $UEC perfectly aligns with this strategy as it operates in a sector with imminent policy shifts, high regulatory costs, and clear deregulation momentum. 9/10

Regulatory costs have become substantial: Companies spend an average of $12,800 per employee annually on compliance. For manufacturing firms, this jumps to $29,100. Federal regulation costs an estimated $2.1T annually ($15K per household). 8/10

The uranium market fundamentals are compelling: Annual supply deficit of 30-40M pounds, limited new mine developments (7-10+ year timeline for new projects), and reduced secondary supply sources. 7/10

Key regulatory reforms include expedited reactor licensing (18-month approval target), capacity expansion goals (from 100GW to 400GW by 2050), and streamlined NRC processes with fixed deadlines for approvals. 6/10

Trump‚Äôs nuclear strategy prioritizes expanding domestic uranium production and enrichment, adding 5GW from existing reactors, and building 10 new reactors. $UEC ‚Äôs stock surge following recent executive orders. 5/10

Why $UEC? As America‚Äôs largest and fastest-growing uranium supplier, $UEC is strategically positioned at the intersection of energy independence and deregulation. The company has strong financials: $271M in cash/inventory/equities, zero debt. 4/10

The secret weapon? $FMKT ‚Äôs proprietary R2Q AI system cross-references 10-Ks, earnings calls, and policy databases in real-time. It scores companies using 7 financial metrics: SG&A efficiency, operating margin, ROIC, FCF, and momentum. 3/10

$FMKT ‚Äôs strategy: Target U.S. firms positioned to benefit from deregulation using AI-powered screening. The fund seeks long-term returns by identifying companies facing high regulatory costs that could thrive in a more favorable regulatory environment. 2/10
